description: From Middle French pétrifier, from Medieval Latin petrificāre, from Latin petra (“rock”), from Ancient Greek πέτρα (pétra, “rock”) + -ficāre, from facere (“do, make”), equivalent to petro- +‎ -ify.

verbs.description: petrify (third-person singular simple present petrifies, present participle petrifying, simple past and past participle petrified)

entries.meaning: To harden organic matter by permeating with water and depositing dissolved minerals.
examples: a river that petrifies any sort of wood or leaves

entries.meaning: To produce rigidity akin to stone.
(intransitive) To become stone, or of a stony hardness, as organic matter by calcareous deposits.
(intransitive, figurative) To become stony, callous, or obdurate.
examples: Like Niobe we marble grow, / And petrify with grief.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To make callous or obdurate; to stupefy; to paralyze; to transform; as by petrification.
examples: A hideous fatalism, which ought, logically, to petrify your volition.
